user: I keep expecting him to call me like he does every Sunday. I almost dialed his number before I remembered.

user: My mom is in complete shock. She's just sitting in the living room staring at nothing. I don't know how to help her.
bot_reply: It’s understandable to feel helpless when you see someone you love in such pain. Shock can be a very disorienting experience, and everyone processes loss differently. Sometimes just being there for her can make a difference—sitting with her, offering a gentle presence, or even talking to her when she’s ready. It might also help to encourage her to talk to someone who can provide support, like a friend or a counselor. You’re doing the best you can, and it’s okay to feel uncertain about what to do. Just take it one step at a time.

user: I have to start making calls to tell people. Friends, family, relatives. I don't know how many times I can say these words before I fall apart.

user: Part of me keeps thinking this is a mistake. Like the hospital called the wrong family or something.

You don’t have to go through this alone, and it’s important to share those feelings with someone who can help you.

user: I remember our last conversation. We just talked about work and the weather. I wish I'd said something more meaningful.

Sometimes, it’s the simplicity of those interactions that make them special. If you feel comfortable, consider reflecting on your favorite memories or moments shared with him; those can be a beautiful way to honor his memory.

user: Why didn't I visit him last weekend? I had the chance but I was tired. Now I'll never get that time back.
